Hitchhiking: Hitchhiking can be a viable option if all public transport stops working. It's a cost-effective and adventurous way to travel long distances. You can use a mobile app to find potential rides, and always prioritize safety by checking the driver's credentials and letting someone know your travel plans.

Carpooling: Carpooling with friends or family members can be an efficient way to travel long distances without a car. You can split the cost of fuel and tolls, and take turns driving to make the journey more comfortable and enjoyable.

Walking: Walking is a healthy and sustainable way to travel long distances. It may take longer than other modes of transportation, but it can be a great way to explore new places and get some exercise. You can use a map or GPS app to plan your route and find accommodations along the way.

Train travel: If trains are still operating, you can use them to travel long distances. Trains can cover vast distances and are often more comfortable and convenient than other modes of transportation. You can use a train scheduling app to plan your trip and book your tickets in advance.

Ride-sharing services: Ride-sharing services like Uber or Lyft can be a convenient way to travel long distances without a car. You can use their mobile app to find a ride and book a trip, and they often have options for shared rides or carpooling to reduce costs.
